posts.name: Mahir
posts.cooked: We have an elevator that can reach up to Level 3, but we are considering upgrading it to Level 4 and possibly higher. One idea that has come to mind is adding stages to the elevator. However, I’m still unsure about this approach. Currently, we use an SDS elevator.

posts.name: Sameer
posts.cooked: How many stages do you currently have on your elevator?

posts.name: Emil
posts.cooked: I’m assuming that the smallest, innermost stage of the elevator has your scoring mechanism on it. If you were to move the scoring mechanism higher up on that stage or create a small extension to raise it further, it wouldn’t change the total height of the elevator when it’s all the way down. However, when the elevator is fully up, the scoring mechanism would be positioned higher off the ground.

posts.name: hrench
posts.cooked:
If you're still playing robots on April 8, chances are you’re heading to champs.  

The key to success at champs often depends on whether your robot can run Level 4 (L4). Without a functional, reliable L4, most teams struggle to compete effectively. Unless you're expecting to form your own alliance, most teams hope a top-tier alliance will pick them over others—would anyone realistically choose a robot that can't run L4?

In my view, your team should continuously improve your robot throughout the season. There are likely features your current robot can enhance or overcome its limitations. Start working on that now.  

However, it’s easy to stick with what works due to laziness, distractions like prom, or other activities. Motivation can wane as the season progresses.

Still, if your goal is to win, you need an L4. Dismissing advice won’t help—you have to act if you want results. If you’re just having fun, consider how frustrating losing feels. In 2012, we were one of the last teams in Galileo with a non-functional robot, and despite knowing the issues, we didn’t fix them. Back then, testing was challenging, and many teams lacked practice bots.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Bob Hrenchir, mechanical build mentor, team 1108, Paola, KS

posts.name: Andrew
posts.cooked:
I don’t know if you’re going to CHAMPS or not, so I’ll make a list for both scenarios. If you are going to CHAMPs, I’d recommend not upgrading the elevator. While L4 and Barge are essential at Worlds to perform well, the time we have right now is limited. Adding a new stage to extend your elevator is risky—it might require manufacturing new parts, purchasing new components, wiring, and programming. There are too many variables to manage, and even if you complete the elevator, your robot could become inconsistent due to rushed construction, which is often frowned upon during alliance selections.

Instead, I suggest improving existing parts and fine-tuning auto operations to ensure each subsystem runs consistently—about 10-12 times without issues or minimal errors. This consistency can help achieve the luck needed to excel at CHAMPs.

If you aren’t going to CHAMPs, it’s up to you. Skipping the elevator upgrade will save time for other activities and preserve parts for next year. However, completing the elevator upgrade could be a good off-season project to teach new or returning members new skills.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 5013 Pit Crew and Design (I do not speak for my team, just my opinions)

posts.name: Mahir
posts.cooked: We managed to qualify for the state competition but did not advance to the world championships. These ideas are meant to help us prepare for the upcoming Invitational competition in October, where we aim to earn better scores.

posts.name: Mahir
posts.cooked: I also think that it is a good offseason project because for almost any game that involves picking and placing components, you will need an elevator. However, there are exceptions at times.

posts.name: Mahir
posts.cooked: We have solved the issue, but we need longer aluminum tubing to elevate higher since we already have all other components.

posts.name: Riley Brewer
posts.cooked: It looks like you have a 2-stage elevator, so you would need to extend the height of each stage. I think your carriage can probably stay the same, which would preserve the geometry of the funnel handoff to the end effector.
